articles.headline: U.S. News Dropped Columbia’s Ranking, but Its Own Methods Are Now Questioned
articles.snippet: After doubt about its data, the university dropped to No. 18 from No. 2. But now many are asking, can the rating system be that easily manipulated?
articles.abstract: After doubt about its data, the university dropped to No. 18 from No. 2. But now many are asking, can the rating system be that easily manipulated?
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. News & World Report likes to say that it is performing a consumer service when it puts out its annual college rankings. But on Monday, those ratings were again called into question after the publication demoted Columbia University to No. 18 from No. 2 in its newest annual list, after a monthslong controversy over whether the school had fudged its numbers.

articles.headline: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
articles.lead_paragraph: DNIPROPETRIVSK REGION, Ukraine — After Ukraine’s stunning offensive in its northeast drove Russian forces into a chaotic retreat and reshaped the battlefield by hundreds of miles, Ukrainian leaders on Monday were weighing critical gambles that could determine the near-term course of the war.

articles.headline: Strike Threat on Freight Railroads Is New Supply Chain Worry
articles.snippet: Administration officials are pushing for a settlement to head off a walkout by tens of thousands of workers on Friday.
articles.abstract: Administration officials are pushing for a settlement to head off a walkout by tens of thousands of workers on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials are racing to prevent a strike by tens of thousands of freight railroad workers that could further disrupt an already strained supply chain and cause billions of dollars in economic damage.

articles.headline: As Russian Losses Mount in Ukraine, So Does Criticism Back Home
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 40 local elected officials across Russia signed a two-sentence petition on Monday that ended with: “We demand the resignation of Vladimir Putin from the post of president of the Russian Federation!”

articles.headline: King Charles Inherits Untold Riches, and Passes Off His Own Empire
articles.snippet: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
articles.abstract: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III built his own empire long before he inherited his mother’s.
articles.byline: By Jane Bradley and Euan Ward

articles.headline: This Might Not Be a Cold War, but It Feels Like One
articles.snippet: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
articles.abstract: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a trip to China more than a decade ago as vice president, Joe Biden gave a speech celebrating the United States as the wealthiest country ever. The United States, he said, was two and a half times as rich as his host nation.

articles.headline: Markets Plunge as Inflation Data Undercuts Wall Street’s Optimism
articles.snippet: Stocks plunged, government bond yields soared and the dollar bounced after investors were wrong-footed by a report showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
articles.abstract: Stocks plunged, government bond yields soared and the dollar bounced after investors were wrong-footed by a report showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks plummeted and government bond yields soared on Tuesday, as investors were once again caught off guard by the persistence of inflation in the United States and quickly shifted their views on what the Federal Reserve may need to do to combat rising prices.

articles.headline: Inflation Remained Stubbornly High in August, Rattling Consumers and Investors
articles.snippet: Overall inflation moderated less than anticipated, and a closely watched measure of price pressures jumped, bad news for the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Overall inflation moderated less than anticipated, and a closely watched measure of price pressures jumped, bad news for the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Price increases remained uncomfortably rapid in August as a broad array of goods and services became more expensive even as gas prices fell, evidence that the sustainable inflation slowdown the Federal Reserve and White House have been hoping for remains elusive.

articles.headline: Pandemic Aid Cut U.S. Poverty to New Low in 2021, Census Bureau Reports
articles.snippet: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies also showed a reduction of almost half in the number of children below the poverty level.
articles.abstract: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies also showed a reduction of almost half in the number of children below the poverty level.
articles.lead_paragraph: A second year of emergency pandemic aid from the federal government drove poverty to the lowest level on record in 2021 and cut the number of poor children by nearly half, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Lydia DePillis and Jason DeParle
